chortle.meaning_1: verb: to chuckle, laugh merrily, often in a breathy, muffled way
chortle.sentence_1: Walking into the cafe, I could hear happy, chortling people and smell the rich aroma of roasted coffee beans.

incisive.meaning_1: adjective: having or demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions
incisive.sentence_1: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopelessly tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.

rustic.meaning_1: adjective: characteristic of rural life; awkwardly simple and provincial
rustic.sentence_1: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

culpability.sentence_1: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.

volubility.meaning_1: noun: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
volubility.sentence_1: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

reticent.meaning_1: adjective: disinclined to talk, not revealing one's thoughts
reticent.sentence_1: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.

querulous.sentence_1: The querulous old woman was beginning to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.

prescience.meaning_1: noun: the power to foresee the future
prescience.sentence_1: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.

mawkish.meaning_1: adjective: overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting
mawkish.sentence_1: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illness by the end of the movie.

concede.sentence_2: After a long, stern lecture from her father, Olivia conceded to having broken the window.
concede.meaning_3: verb: give over; surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another
concede.sentence_3: The Spanish were forced to concede much of the territory they had previously conquered.

predilection.sentence_1: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

gall.sentence_1: The speeding car had the gall to switch five lanes at once, run through a red light, and then cut off a police car before finally coming to a stop in front of a sea of flashing red lights.
gall.sentence_2: In an act of gall, Leah sent compromising photos of her ex-boyfriend to all his co-workers and professional contacts.
gall.meaning_2: noun: feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill-will
gall.meaning_1: noun: the trait of being rude and impertinent

glut.sentence_1: The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.
glut.sentence_2: In the middle of economic crises, hiring managers find their inboxes glutted with resumes.
glut.meaning_2: verb: supply with an excess of

Magoosh Blog.meaning_1: noun: A place to find valuable information including study schedules and GRE tips. Learn more at http://magoosh.com/gre
Magoosh Blog.sentence_1: Lena used the 1 month study schedule on the Magoosh blog to score well on the GRE.

dictatorial.meaning_1: adjective: expecting unquestioning obedience; characteristic of an absolute ruler
dictatorial.sentence_1: The coach was dictatorial in his approach: no players could ever argue or question his approach.

gainsay.meaning_1: verb: deny or contradict; speak against or oppose
gainsay.sentence_1: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.

obscure.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions, but these are the most important ones to study
obscure.sentence_1: On the Smith's drive through the Grand Canyon, Mr. Smith's big head obscured much of Mrs. Robinson's view, so that she only saw momentary patches of red rock.
obscure.sentence_2: Many of the biggest movie stars were once obscure actors who got only bit roles in long forgotten films.
obscure.meaning_2: adjective: known by only a few

germane.sentence_1: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

didactic.sentence_1: Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Ilyich is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.

torpor.meaning_1: noun: inactivity resulting from lethargy and lack of vigor or energy
torpor.sentence_1: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.

bucolic.meaning_1: adjective: relating to the pleasant aspects of the country
bucolic.sentence_1: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.

inexorable.meaning_1: adjective: impossible to stop or prevent
inexorable.sentence_1: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.

frivolous.meaning_1: adjective: not serious in content or attitude or behavior
frivolous.sentence_1: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.

superfluous.sentence_1: How can we hope to stay open if we don't eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupuncture Tuesday?
superfluous.sentence_2: The third paragraph in your essay is superfluous and can be deleted.
superfluous.meaning_2: adjective: more than is needed, desired, or required

cryptic.meaning_1: adjective: mysterious or vague, usually intentionally
cryptic.sentence_1: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

deferential.sentence_1: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

recondite.meaning_1: adjective: difficult to penetrate; incomprehensible to one of ordinary understanding or knowledge
recondite.sentence_1: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

perfidy.meaning_1: noun: an act of deliberate betrayal; a breach of a trust
perfidy.sentence_1: Sure, he was the best salesman in the company; but Michael had abused the trust of the firm, sharing product secrets with a competitor, and for such perfidy he was terminated.

vociferous.meaning_1: adjective: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
vociferous.sentence_1: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around and look at them angrily.

aesthetic.sentence_1: The director, not known for his aesthetic sensibilities, decided not to use costumes at all, and put on the play in everyday clothing.
aesthetic.sentence_2: The artist operated according to a peculiar aesthetic, not considering any photograph to be worth publishing unless it contained a marine mammal.
aesthetic.meaning_2: noun: a set of principles underlying and guiding the work of a particular artist or artistic movement.
aesthetic.meaning_1: adjective: concerned with the appreciation of beauty

platitude.meaning_1: noun: a trite or obvious remark
platitude.sentence_1: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.

banal.meaning_1: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
banal.sentence_1: The professor used such banal expression that many students in the class either fell asleep from boredom or stayed awake to complete his sentences and humor friends.

engender.sentence_1: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

exacerbate.sentence_1: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

diffident.meaning_1: adjective: showing modest reserve; lacking self-confidence
diffident.sentence_1: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

entrenched.sentence_1: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

preclude.meaning_1: verb: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
preclude.sentence_1: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.

dogmatic.meaning_1: adjective: highly opinionated, not accepting that your belief may not be correct
dogmatic.sentence_1: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.

meticulous.meaning_1: adjective: marked by extreme care in treatment of details
meticulous.sentence_1: The Japanese noodle maker was meticulous in making his noodles and would never let another person take over the task.

audacious.meaning_1: adjective: willing to be bold in social situations or to take risks
audacious.sentence_1: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.

decorous.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct
decorous.sentence_1: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.

apathetic.meaning_1: adjective: marked by a lack of interest
apathetic.sentence_1: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.

eschew.meaning_1: verb: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
eschew.sentence_1: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.

aesthete.meaning_1: noun: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature
aesthete.sentence_1: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.

mitigate.sentence_1: I can only spend so much time mitigating your disagreements with your wife, and at certain point, you need to do it on your own.
mitigate.sentence_2: If it weren't for the mitigating circumstances, he would have certainly lost his job.
mitigate.meaning_2: verb: lessen the severity of an offense
mitigate.meaning_1: verb: make less severe or harsh

conspicuous.meaning_1: adjective: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
conspicuous.sentence_1: American basketball players are always conspicuous when they go abroad--not only are they American, but some are over seven feet tall.

gossamer.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy
gossamer.sentence_1: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.

lambast.sentence_1: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

fortuitous.meaning_1: adjective: occurring by happy chance; having no cause or apparent cause
fortuitous.sentence_1: Though Maria's neighbor Ernie "bumped into" her at the Farmer's Market, the encounter wasn't nearly as fortuitous as Maria was led to believe: Ernie desperately wanted to ask Maria out on a date and had been following her about town.

impudent.sentence_1: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.
